title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with evidence showing disparities in legal representation and execution rates. Since 1976, African-Americans account for 35% of executions, 43% on death row nationwide, and 67% on death row in the Federal system. 84% of victims in death penalty cases are white, despite only 50% of murder victims being white. A 1994 study found that 89% of defendants selected for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. In 1990, the General Accounting Office reported racial disparities in the criminal justice system. In 1990, the General Accounting Office reported racial disparities in the criminal justice system, including disparities in charging, sentencing, and imposition of the death penalty. Prisoner appeals have been restricted since 1976, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent people. New legislation in 1996 limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals. In 1996, new legislation limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners, even when presented with compelling evidence of innocence. The Federal and State death penalty is on hold until Congress reviews the final findings of the National Commission on the Death Penalty and enacts legislation based on their recommendations. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, and judges. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including attorneys experienced in capital defense, current or former Federal or State judges, and current or former Federal or State law enforcement officials. Additionally, there are 5 members from the public or private sector with knowledge or expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including individuals from academia, nonprofit organizations, the religious community, industry, and other interested individuals. The President aims to ensure a balanced viewpoint on the use of the death penalty among Commission members. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission with vacancies filled promptly. The Commission, consisting of 15 members appointed by the President, must be established within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, with vacancies promptly filled. The Commission must hold its initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the Chairperson's call. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for conducting business, and the President designates a Chair from the appointed members. The Commission will adopt rules and procedures to govern its proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is required to conduct a comprehensive study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles of fairness, justice, equality, and due process. This study will include examining racial disparities, disproportionality based on geographic location and income status, and the adequacy of representation for capital defendants. The study by the Commission will also consider the adequacy of representation for capital defendants, innocence of individuals sentenced to death, and whether the Federal government should pursue the death penalty in states without it. The study by the Commission will also consider issues such as wrongful convictions, federal pursuit of death penalty in states without it, independent judgment in constitutional claims, sentencing of mentally retarded and juvenile offenders to death, and access to forensic evidence for individuals sentenced to death. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for the administration of the death penalty, ensuring access to forensic evidence and fair administration of death penalty cases in accordance with the Constitution. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for the administration of the death penalty to ensure fair and impartial execution of cases, minimize the risk of wrongful executions, and prevent racial discrimination in the process. Additionally, a preliminary report will be submitted to the President, Attorney General, and Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within one year of the Act's enactment, containing findings and conclusions. A final report will be submitted within 2 years, with detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. SEC. 203. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the power to obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary to carry out its provisions. The Commission, subcommittee, or member may hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to compel witnesses and evidence. Subpoenas must be signed by the Chairperson and enforced in cases of non-compliance. The Chairperson of the Commission must sign subpoenas, which can be enforced by the district court in cases of non-compliance. Testimony of persons in custody can be sought by the Commission through a court of the United States within its jurisdiction. The court can issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person in custody before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees will be paid according to the provisions of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws, subject to confirmation by the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The compensation for the executive director and personnel is determined by the Chairperson, with a maximum rate set at level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It may spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
